description.plain:
Bashar Barakah Jackson (July 20, 1999 – February 19, 2020), better known by his stage name Pop Smoke, was a rapper from Canarsie, Brooklyn, New York. He started getting popularity from his April 2019 single “Welcome To The Party,” which was boosted by support from A$AP Ferg. Smoke also used a signature and distinguishable drill-style rap in his music, the style that is typically seen in the UK rap scene.

In an interview with Real 92.3 LA, Pop Smoke cited some of his main influences being 50 Cent, DMX and Meek Mill.

His debut project, Meet the Woo, was released on July 26, 2019.

In August 2019, multiple remixes of “Welcome To The Party” were released, further boosting the song and Smoke’s popularity. Smoke continued his rise even later in 2019, having a high-profile placement on Houston rapper Travis Scott and JACKBOYS‘ December 2019 track “GATTI.”

In 2020, his meteoric rise to fame continued with the release of his second project Meet the Woo 2 on February 7.

Tragically, Pop Smoke was shot and killed in a home invasion in Los Angeles, California on February 19, 2020. He was 20 years old.

On July 3, 2020, his debut album and first posthumous project Shoot for the Stars Aim for the Moon was released. The record debuted at #1 on the Billboard 200, marking Pop’s first #1 album on the chart. The deluxe version of the record was subsequently released on July 20, 2020, which would have been Pop’s 21st birthday.

On July 16, 2021, Pop Smoke’s management team released his second posthumous project, Faith, and followed up with its deluxe version on July 31.

songs.full_title: Dior by Pop Smoke
songs.title: Dior

description.plain:
“Dior” is Pop Smoke’s most popular solo song to date. It is part of both of Pop’s mixtapes, Meet the Woo and Meet the Woo 2. It was also included as a bonus track on Pop’s posthumous debut album, Shoot for the Stars Aim for the Moon. It debuted and peaked at #30 on the Billboard Hot 100.

On February 19, 2020, Pop was tragically shot and killed. The song became popular after his death and re-entered the Billboard Hot 100 in the following week.

The track’s official music video was released on September 3, 2019.

songs.title: Mood Swings

description.plain:
“Mood Swings“ sees Pop Smoke reuniting with Bronx rapper Lil Tjay for a slow-moving track. The two take turns dropping references to their women and expensive items to boast about their lifestyle with fame.

Pop and Tjay made this track the same night they made their October 2019 hit “War,“ a track which was featured on Pop’s 2020 mixtape, Meet The Woo 2.

songs.full_title: Welcome to the Party by Pop Smoke
songs.title: Welcome to the Party

description.plain:
Featuring hard-hitting production from UK drill producer 808Melo, “Welcome to the Party” is a drill banger and the breakout hit for Brooklyn-native rapper Pop Smoke.

The track served as the second single to his debut mixtape Meet the Woo. Released on April 23, 2019, the song would go onto gain widespread attention and popularity and remixed by many artists in the rap game, including the likes of: ASAP Ferg, Dave East, Kiing Shooter, Meek Mill, Pusha T and Rico Nasty.

Pop Smoke would release two official remixes however, with fellow rappers in Nicki Minaj and Skepta.

The instrumental for the song was originally posted by 808Melo on his SoundCloud page with the title “John Doe Part 3” (and presumably on YouTube as well, although it no longer exists on 808Melo’s YouTube page) before it was used by Pop Smoke.

The track served as the second single to his debut mixtape Meet the Woo. Released on April 23, 2019, the song would go onto gain widespread attention and popularity and remixed by many artists in the rap game, including the likes of: ASAP Ferg, Dave East, Kiing Shooter, Meek Mill, Pusha T and Rico Nasty.

Pop Smoke would release two official remixes however, with fellow rappers in Nicki Minaj and Skepta.

The instrumental for the song was originally posted by 808Melo on his SoundCloud page with the title “John Doe Part 3” (and presumably on YouTube as well, although it no longer exists on 808Melo’s YouTube page) before it was used by Pop Smoke.

songs.full_title: For the Night by Pop Smoke (Ft. DaBaby & Lil Baby)
songs.title: For the Night
songs.title_with_featured: For the Night (Ft. DaBaby & Lil Baby)

description.plain:
“For The Night” is the 3rd track off of the late Pop Smoke’s album, Shoot for the Stars Aim for the Moon. Besides being off a highly anticipated album, the song was also highly popularized due to a Tiktok dance surrounding the song.

This song marks the first collaboration between Pop, Lil Baby, and DaBaby. On a beat produced by CashMoneyAP and MIKE DEAN, the trio talk about their nighttime activities, how they act around women, and their now-lavish lifestyles. The song points to how the rappers don’t want a long-term relationship, wanting only a companion, “For the Night”.

songs.full_title: Got It on Me by Pop Smoke
songs.title: Got It on Me

description.plain:
“Got It On Me” samples and interpolates executive producer 50 Cent’s May 2003 track “Many Men (Wish Death)” and features many of the same themes as the iconic track, including Pop wishing for mercy from those who are out to attack him.

The song was featured in the album trailer for Shoot for the Stars, Aim for the Moon on June 10, 2020, and its title was confirmed via Shazam.

The verses were taken from Pop’s Power 106 Freestyle, shown here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=x1YHynM540A

songs.full_title: The Woo by Pop Smoke (Ft. 50 Cent & Roddy Ricch)
songs.title: The Woo

description.plain:
The Woo’s are a gang alliance of Bloods and Crips in Brooklyn, New York, Pop Smoke’s hometown.

The late rapper popularized the refrain “Woo” and transcended its original meaning to a lifestyle of swagger and luxury. Pop Smoke is typically referred to as the “Woo” and so this braggadocios song is about the women who want to be with him for his lifestyle. Hence his two mixtapes, Meet The Woo and Meet The Woo 2.

description.plain: Pop Smoke and Nicki Minaj have united for their first collaboration on “Welcome to the Party (Remix).” Smoke is a leader in the growing New York drill music scene, and Nicki was an early supporter of the track. The song was first teased on Pop Smoke’s Instagram Live, where he streamed an audio clip of Nicki’s verse.

songs.full_title: Enjoy Yourself by Pop Smoke (Ft. KAROL G)
songs.title: Enjoy Yourself

description.plain:
“Enjoy Yourself” is a track from deceased Brooklyn rapper Pop Smoke, in collaboration with Colombian singer KAROL G. Originally, the featured artist was Nigerian singer Burna Boy however the version of the song with him became the last track on the deluxe edition of the album.

A snippet of the song was revealed on this footage of a studio session in which the rapper can be seen working on the track alongside his engineer.

On the day of Shoot for the Stars, Aim for the Moon’s release, Tyga, who collaborated with Pop on the track “West Coast Shit,” shared via Instagram that Pop initially sent the song to him and expressed interest in featuring “one of those Latin chicks on it,” to which Tyga suggested KAROL G.

songs.full_title: Invincible by Pop Smoke
songs.title: Invincible

description.plain:
“Invincible” is the introductory track to the mixtape Meet the Woo 2 by New York rapper Pop Smoke. This song talks more on the changes in Pop Smoke’s life since his stardom began growing in 2019.

He goes in depth the people he has met, like Diddy, DJ Clue? and DJ SpinKing, as well as why he reigns more superior than other opponents in aspects of using weapons and the differences in how they spend their money.

songs.full_title: PTSD by Pop Smoke
songs.title: PTSD

description.plain:
On “PTSD,” Pop opens up about the post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) that he suffers from due to the horrific violence he has witnessed in the streets of New York.

The song features Pop taking an introspective perspective, opting to sing in a manner reminiscent of his mentor 50 Cent rather than his usual rapping style. This singing style would later be used heavily on Pop’s posthumous debut album Shoot for the Stars, Aim for the Moon.

songs.full_title: Gangstas by Pop Smoke
songs.title: Gangstas

description.plain:
On “Gangstas,” Pop Smoke affirms his authenticity in the streets, rapping about his deadly crew from New York and staying strapped in case someone messes with him. The song appears to take shots at fellow New York rapper 6ix9ine, who’s known for his “rainbow-colored hair” and “loud” rapping as Pop notes in the song’s intro.

In an August 2019 interview with Real 92.3, Pop commented on 6ix9ine’s street cred and how he was pushed by other people into portraying someone he wasn’t:

He was doing his thing. Niggas can’t take that away from the homie. I don’t think he was a real street nigga, you feel me? And I feel like that’s where people fucked up by portraying, making him portray that shit. He’s not a street nigga. I think he was trying to portray something he really didn’t understand.

Additionally, in February 2020, Pop Smoke took jabs at 6ix9ine on social media while promoting his then-upcoming mixtape, Meet The Woo 2, where he claimed he didn’t “need rainbow hair” to sell records.

The song was leaked on June 29, 2020, four days before its official release.

songs.title: Tell the Vision
songs.title_with_featured: Tell the Vision (Ft. Kanye West & Pusha T)

description.plain:
On “Tell The Vision,” the late Pop Smoke, along with the veteran rappers Kanye West and Pusha T, rap about how they made it to the top and how their lifestyle has changed due to them becoming popular.

The song’s title first appeared on one of Ye’s tracklists for his tenth studio album, Donda. Pop Smoke’s vocals were taken from his unreleased song, “We Made It” with Chicago rapper Calboy.

songs.full_title: 44 BullDog by Pop Smoke
songs.title: 44 BullDog

description.plain:
On “44 BullDog,” Pop raps about the Charter Arms Bulldog, a 5-shot traditional double-action revolver available for the .44 Special and .357 Magnum cartridges.

The song’s instrumental was originally from Nito NB’s “Lightwork Freestyle” and was also used by Russ Millions on his November 2018 single “Trick Or Treat,” as well as Nas Blixky on his song “No Cap.”

songs.full_title: Aim for the Moon by Pop Smoke (Ft. Quavo)
songs.title: Aim for the Moon

description.plain:
“Aim For The Moon,” the titular track from Smoke’s posthumous record Shoot for the Stars, Aim for the Moon, is a powerful track featuring Smoke and Migos rapper Quavo bragging about their status and high aspirations in the music industry.

The song was first previewed by rapper and acquaintance of Smoke, Travis Scott. Travis posted a clip of the song on his Instagram story on February 19, 2020, which was also the day that Smoke passed away. On May 25, 2020, the song appeared online in its entirety.

songs.full_title: Christopher Walking by Pop Smoke
songs.title: Christopher Walking

description.plain:
“Christopher Walking” is the first single from Pop Smoke’s sophomore and sequel studio album, Meet The Woo 2. The track features Smoke comparing himself to Frank White, Christopher Walken’s character in the 1990 crime film King of New York, which is also the nickname of White in the film.

Pop first teased the track on January 13, 2020, posting a snippet of the track’s chorus to Instagram. He later revealed the track’s title and release date with another Instagram post on January 15, 2020, the day before the track’s release.

songs.full_title: Make It Rain by Pop Smoke (Ft. Rowdy Rebel)
songs.title: Make It Rain

description.plain:
“Make It Rain” is the lead single from Pop Smoke’s posthumous debut studio album, Shoot for the Stars, Aim for the Moon. On the track, Pop Smoke and Rowdy Rebel rap about “making it rain” bullets upon their enemies.

The track was first announced on June 10, 2020, in a post made by Pop Smoke’s manager, Steven Victor. He explained that the single would be released instead of the album, which is what was originally planned for June 12, 2020. This delay occurred out of respect for worldwide protests and unrest happening at the time, specifically regarding the murder of George Floyd and other black people at the hands of police.

The initial announcement of the song revealed that there would be a secret feature on the track, which eventually turned out to be Rowdy Rebel, the iconic member of GS9 that was incarcerated at the song’s release. This is why his verse was recorded over a telephone.

songs.title: Woo Baby

description.plain:
On “Woo Baby”, Chris Brown and Pop Smoke collide for the first time on an upbeat sexual R&B track.

Interestingly, early snippets show that Ontario singer Tory Lanez was supposed to be on this record. His verse was removed for the final cut, presumably due to his controversy with rapper Megan Thee Stallion.
